descriptionSet.description: In this image, houses can be seen dotting the valley and the hills. In the background mountains that have been partially obscured by clouds can be seen. The hills and valley are covered with trees and vegetation.

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: 96554
text-en: The Bazar, Solan Hill (India).

description-en: In this image, houses can be seen dotting the valley and the hills. In the background mountains that have been partially obscured by clouds can be seen. The hills and valley are covered with trees and vegetation. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The card shown here is a typical example of the picturesque aesthetic. Solan, a satellite station of Simla, was the site of a military hospital and a brewery. In the picture, the object of interest is the native bazar on Solan Hill seen from a higher elevation with a tree in the foreground framing the picture. Conforming to a conventional picturesque view, it has variety and contrast in the roughness and the smoothness of the terrain and in areas of darkness and light. As stipulated in the earliest manual of the picturesque aesthetic by William Gilpin in 1782, there are three planes within the composition with the object of interest occupying the middle ground, and the trees in the foreground providing a darker frame to direct the eye to the object of interest, in this case the native bazaar. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The bazar occupies the middle ground of the image. It is at a lower elevation than other areas in the station, which would be the case for Native areas versus those occupied by Europeans. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)
related literature: Anzai S. 2005. “Transplantation of the Picturesque.” In: Dowler L, Carubia J, Szczygiel B Gender and Landscape. 1st. London and New York: Routledge. pp. 55-74. (gs)

related literature: Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714. (gs)
related literature: Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230. (gs)
related literature: Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press. (gs)
related literature: Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" (gs)
